Issues.Title: fix(ivy): better inference for circularly referenced directive types
Issues.Body:
It's possible to pass a directive as an input to itself. Consider:

```html
<some-cmp #ref [value]="ref">
```

Since the template type-checker attempts to infer a type for `<some-cmp>`
using the values of its inputs, this creates a circular reference where the
type of the `value` input is used in its own inference:

```typescript
var _t0 = SomeCmp.ngTypeCtor({value: _t0});
```

Obviously, this doesn't work. To resolve this, the template type-checker
used to generate a `null!` expression when a reference would otherwise be
circular:

```typescript
var _t0 = SomeCmp.ngTypeCtor({value: null!});
```

This effectively asks TypeScript to infer a value for this context, and
works well to resolve this simple cycle. However, if the template
instead tries to use the circular value in a larger expression:

```html
<some-cmp #ref [value]="ref.prop">
```

The checker would generate:

```typescript
var _t0 = SomeCmp.ngTypeCtor({value: (null!).prop});
```

In this case, TypeScript can't figure out any way `null!` could have a
`prop` key, and so it infers `never` as the type. `(never).prop` is thus a
type error.

This commit implements a better fallback pattern for circular references to
directive types like this. Instead of generating a `null!` in place for the
reference, a type is inferred by calling the type constructor again with
`null!` as its input. This infers the widest possible type for the directive
which is then used to break the cycle:

```typescript
var _t0 = SomeCmp.ngTypeCtor(null!);
var _t1 = SomeCmp.ngTypeCtor({value: _t0.prop});
```

This has the desired effect of validating that `.prop` is legal for the
directive type (the type of `#ref`) while also avoiding a cycle.

Fixes #35372
Fixes #35603
Fixes #35522
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): better inference for circularly referenced directive types" (#35622)

Issues.Title: fix(ivy): provide a more detailed error message for NG6002/NG6003
Issues.Body:
NG6002/NG6003 are errors produced when an NgModule being compiled has an
imported or exported type which does not have the proper metadata (that is,
it doesn't appear to be an @NgModule, or @Directive, etc. depending on
context).

Previously this error message was a bit sparse. However, Github issues show
that this is the most common error users receive when for whatever reason
ngcc wasn't able to handle one of their libraries, or they just didn't run
it. So this commit changes the error message to offer a bit more useful
context, instructing users differently depending on whether the class in
question is from their own project, from NPM, or from a monorepo-style local
dependency.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ivy): provide a more detailed error message for NG6002/NG6003" (#35620)

Issues.Title: refactor(compiler): Remove NullAstVisitor and visitAstChildren
Issues.Body:
This commit removes the `NullAstVisitor` and `visitAstChildren` exported
from `packages/compiler/src/expression_parser/ast.ts` because they
contain duplicate and buggy implementation, and their use cases could be
sufficiently covered by `RecursiveAstVisitor` if the latter implements the
`visit` method. This use case is only needed in the language service.

With this change, any visitor that extends `RecursiveAstVisitor` could
just define their own `visit` function and the parent class will behave
correctly.

### A bit of historical context:
In language service, we need a way to tranverse the expression AST in a
selective manner based on where the user's cursor is. This means we need a
"filtering" function to decide which node to visit and which node to not
visit. Instead of refactoring `RecursiveAstVisitor` to support this,
`visitAstChildren` was created. `visitAstChildren` duplicates the
implementation of `RecursiveAstVisitor`, but introduced some bugs along
the way. For example, in `visitKeyedWrite`, it visits
```
obj -> key -> obj
```
instead of
```
obj -> key -> value
```

Moreover, because of the following line
```
visitor.visit && visitor.visit(ast, context) || ast.visit(visitor, context);
```
`visitAstChildren` visits every node **twice**.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(compiler): Remove NullAstVisitor and visitAstChildren" (#35619)

Issues.Title: docs: Changed ng deploy to firebase deploy
Issues.Body:
ng deploy didn't work for me for a very long time of me trying. But after seeing issue @2227 https://github.com/angular/angularfire/issues/2227 It seems clear that ng deploy currently have problems; while firebase deploy doesn't. If this is meant for beginners, beginners should ever see any bugs or problems early on.

app.component.ts 

import { Component, OnInit, Inject } from '@angular/core';
import { UserInfoService } from './infrastructure/userinfo.service';
import { BroadcastService, MsalService } from '@azure/msal-angular';
import { Subscription } from 'rxjs';
import { PageHeaderService, PageHeaderModel } from './infrastructure/pageheader.service.service';

@Component({
    selector: 'app-root',
    templateUrl: './app.component.html',
    styleUrls: ['./app.component.css']
})
export class AppComponent implements OnInit {

    public isIframe: boolean;
    loggedIn: boolean;
    private pageHeaderSubscription: Subscription;
    private userName: string;

    public pageHeaderName: string = "Home";
    public pageHeaderMenuItemId: number;
    public pageHeaderShowPin: boolean;

    constructor(private msalService: MsalService,
        private broadcastService: BroadcastService,
        private uiService: UserInfoService,
        private phService: PageHeaderService,
        @Inject('BASE_URL') private baseUrl: string) {

        //set the client id
        this.SetClientId();

        this.isIframe = window !== window.parent && !window.opener;

        let user = this.msalService.getUser();
        
        if (user) {
            this.loggedIn = true;
            this.userName = user.displayableId.split("@")[0].toLowerCase();
            this.uiService.loadUserInfo(this.userName);
        } else {
            this.loggedIn = false;
        }

        //subscribe to the page header changes
        this.pageHeaderSubscription = this.phService.pageHeaderObservable.subscribe((data: PageHeaderModel) => {
            this.pageHeaderName = data.name;
            this.pageHeaderMenuItemId = data.menuItemId;
            this.pageHeaderShowPin = data.showPin;
        });

    }


    ngOnInit(): void {

        console.log("IN App Component!");

        //Single Sign On
        this.broadcastService.subscribe("msal:loginFailure", (payload) => {
            alert("login failure " + JSON.stringify(payload));
            this.loggedIn = false;
        });

        this.broadcastService.subscribe("msal:loginSuccess", () => {
            this.loggedIn = true;
            this.uiService.loadUserInfo(this.userName);
        });

        if (!this.loggedIn) {
            this.login();
        }

    }

    ngOnDestroy() {

        this.broadcastService.getMSALSubject().next(1);

        if (this.pageHeaderSubscription) {

            this.pageHeaderSubscription.unsubscribe();

        }

    }

    //log the user into the msal service.
    login() {

        this.msalService.loginRedirect();

    }

    //set the client id for the base url
    private SetClientId() {
        switch (this.baseUrl) {
            //Dev
            case `https://anyURL.com/`:
                this.msalService.clientId = 'XXXXXXXX';
                break;
            //Test
            case `https://anyURL.com/`:
                this.msalService.clientId = 'XXXXXX';
                break;
            //Prod
            case `https://anyURL.com/`:
                this.msalService.clientId = 'XXXXXXX';
                break;
            //Local
            default:
                this.msalService.clientId = 'XXXXXX';
        }
    }



}

Issues.Title: Angular UpgradeModule not working with IVY
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages as the source of the bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> The issue is caused by package @angular/upgrade/static

### Is this a regression?
<!-- Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: ....

### Description
In my hybrid AngularJS-Angular application when I've upgrade to Angular 9 I cannot build `ng build` application anymore due to error:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28590512/75014555-d7237f00-5486-11ea-80ff-7c5da3d1b20f.png)


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
1. npm install @angular/upgrade
2. Add in App Module:
`import { UpgradeModule } from "@angular/upgrade/static";`
and add in imports: `UpgradeModule`
3. ng build

## üåç  Your Environment

**Angular Version:**
Angular CLI: 9.0.1
Node: 10.14.2
OS: win32 x64

**Anything else relevant?**
It seems that it occurs only with Ivy, because if I will set in Angular.json `"aot": false` and in tsconfig.json
```
   "angularCompilerOptions": {
        "enableIvy": false
    },
```

Then everything works fine.

Issues.Title: Code example is TestBed.get but description says TestBed.inject in the HTTP guide
Issues.Body:
# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description
The _[Testing HTTP requests](https://angular.io/guide/http#testing-http-requests)_ section of the HTTP guide has contradictory code and explanation.

The method `TestBed.get` is being used but the description says `TestBed.inject`.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
1. Navigate to https://angular.io/guide/http
2. Within that page, go to section _Testing HTTP Requests_ -> _Setup_ (https://angular.io/guide/http#setup-1)
3. Look at the last lines of the block of code named _app/testing/http-client.spec.ts(setup)_ and the description after it

### What's the affected URL?
https://angular.io/guide/http

### Expected vs Actual Behavior
`TestBed.get` should be `TestBed.inject`.

Alternatively, explanation should say _TestBed.get()_ instead of _TestBed.inject()_, but because of what is said in https://angular.io/guide/testing#angular-testbed the first option would be prefered.

## üì∑Screenshot
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/26304638/75021458-5798ae80-548c-11ea-9af1-3313fe33ab10.png)

### Anything else relevant?
Not a duplicate of #30750 because this issue is about a mismatch between the code and the description.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Code example is TestBed.get but description says TestBed.inject in the HTTP guide" (#35609)

Issues.Title: fix(ngcc): capture path-mapped entry-points that start with same string
Issues.Body:
Previously if there were two path-mapped libraries that are in
different directories but the path of one started with same string
as the path of the other, we would incorrectly return the shorter
path - e.g. `dist/my-lib` and `dist/my-lib-second`. This was because
the list of `basePaths` was searched in ascending alphabetic order and
we were using `startsWith()` to match the path.

Now the `basePaths` are searched in reverse alphabetic order so the
longer path will be matched correctly.

// FW-1873

Fixes #35536
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(ngcc): capture path-mapped entry-points that start with same string" (#35592)

Issues.Title: build: exclude redundant cherry-picked commits when generating changelog
Issues.Body: If generating a changelog between tags that are on different branches (e.g., 9.0.3 on 9.0.x and 9.1.0-next.0 on master), commits that were cherry-picked and present in the previous version would also show in the newer version's changelog.  This update analyzes the commits and excludes any that fit this scenario.  Any commits that had conflicts will not be able to be matched authoritatively.  Manual review of the generated changelog may still be needed for attempted cherry-pick commits that had conflicts.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: exclude redundant cherry-picked commits when generating changelog" (#17050)

Issues.Title: refactor(@angular/cli): Update error message when multiple NgModules to auto add a component to are found.
Issues.Body:
The prior message makes it sound like the only option is to skip the auto import. I've just updated it to let people know that there is another way to get the auto module import goodness.

Example of the new message in a dummy repository:
![example_message](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1403638/75046238-beb96180-5492-11ea-8979-bbe71998912a.png)

Issues.Title: Generated Source Maps using absolute paths
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? I don't think so. ### Description When building an Angular application that imports a local library, the source maps for files outside of the apps' folder contain absolute paths instead of relative ones. This happens because the context for the default Webpack config generated by the CLI internally is [set to `projectRoot`](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/c9a5f3ced6689feac9cc0ccbd15b0fed6f454d6e/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/angular-cli-files/models/webpack-configs/common.ts#L497). Webpack shortens the paths by looking into the [current and the parent directory](https://github.com/webpack/webpack/blob/11e94dd2d0a8d8baae75e715ff8a69f27a9e3014/lib/RequestShortener.js#L63), which is not enough for the provided setup. I propose to use either the TSConfig `baseUrl` as the context for the Webpack config (would make the most sense in my opinion because the paths aliases are relative to this path), or the workspaces `root` property. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Create a new project containing an application and a library. Import the library in the application through TS path aliases and build it with source maps enabled. The source maps will be using absolute paths. A simple repo can be found here: https://github.com/FERNman/angular-source-maps Just run `ng build playground` and go to any of the generated source maps in the `dist` folder. The path should be an absolute path. ## Workaround For anybody else stumbling across this issue, an easy workaround until this gets fixed is to change the `root` property of the app in question in the `angular.json` to the repositories' root. ## üåç Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 9.0.1
Node: 12.10.0
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 9.0.0
... animations, cdk, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, material, material-moment-adapter
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router
... service-worker

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): fix  autoprefixer comments support in scss
Issues.Body:
Change Scss output style to `expanded` as otherwise sass will remove comments that are needed for autoprefixer when webpack is in prod mode because of the following implementation in `sass-loader`:
See: https://github.com/webpack-contrib/sass-loader/blob/45ad0be17264ceada5f0b4fb87e9357abe85c4ff/src/getSassOptions.js#L68-L70

Fixes #17041
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): fix  autoprefixer comments support in scss" (#17045)

Issues.Title: Memory Leak when using ng
Issues.Body:
Hi,

There's a memory leak with `ng`, it keeps consuming memory despite memory increase, I've monitored and it has already **consumed more than 17 GB of RAM**! I think the problem is related to SASS because the program is stucked with `.scss` files but I'm not sure.


I've tested with `NODE_OPTIONS=--max-old-space-size=17000` but also `node --max_old_space_size=20000 node_modules/@angular/cli/bin/ng build --prod` later, always the same issue even if I try with `8192` instead of `17000` or `20000`.

I know, this memory problem has already been opened multiple times, like here [#13734](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/13734), but it seems to be a **persistent issue**

Issues.Title: feat(@schematics/angular): Allow empty string in the type option
Issues.Body:
Currently, Component and Class have the options to add custom type. In the case of class, It's already working fine with  an empty string in type but in the case  of component When setting the type to an empty string the file names generated will contain an extra period (.) which breaks the flow.

With this PR, It will generate the files without an extra period (.)

Reference #16811 and #16891
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@schematics/angular): Allow empty string in the type option" (#17040)

Issues.Title: Angular 9 Backward Compatibility for CSS Grids in IE 11
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package Backward Compatibility for CSS Grids in IE 11 ### Is this a regression? Yes, It wasn't an issue in Angular 8 ### Description I have an Angular 8 application which uses CSS Grids. It was compatible with IE 11, Chrome 79+ and Mozilla Firefox 70+. Recently upgraded the app to Angular 9. I have set browserslist to include IE 9-11, and had turned on autoprefixer in the component's scss file like `/* autoprefixer grid: autoplace */` as suggested in [Angular Documentation](Angular 9 Backward Compatibility for CSS Grids in IE 11). When built in prod mode using `ng build --prod` vendor prefixes were not generated for IE 11. ![IE11_CSS_Grids](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11618495/75001125-8a13be80-542e-11ea-8fb1-fa382235ab78.png) But, when I added a configuration for `es5` and served with `ng serve --configuration es5` vendor prefixes were generated and application was rendered exactly as in Chrome. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://github.com/srajkumarms/ie11-grid-support ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 



Angular CLI: 9.0.3
Node: 10.15.3
OS: darwin x64

Issues.Title: Better module imports in VSCode possible?
Issues.Body:
I apologize if this isn't the right place. But I am trying to make VSCode better at importing Angular modules. Take a brand new Angular app created with the CLI as an example. It has the following dependencies installed.
```.json
"dependencies": {
    "@angular/animations": "~9.0.1",
    "@angular/common": "~9.0.1",
    "@angular/compiler": "~9.0.1",
    "@angular/core": "~9.0.1",
    "@angular/forms": "~9.0.1",
    "@angular/platform-browser": "~9.0.1",
    "@angular/platform-browser-dynamic": "~9.0.1",
    "@angular/router": "~9.0.1",
    "rxjs": "~6.5.4",
    "tslib": "^1.10.0",
    "zone.js": "~0.10.2"
  }
``` 
But VSCode can't help importing those modules, like `ReactiveFormsModule` or `HttpClientModule` into `app.module.ts`. It has no clue.  You have to manually type the import statement `import { ReactiveFormsModule } from '@angular/forms';` or adding type definitions to `tsconfig.ts` 

```.json
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "typeRoots": [
      "node_modules/@types",
      "node_modules/@angular",
      "node_modules/@angular/common",
    ],
  },
}
```
  

Is there something to be included in the Language Service that will expose Angular dependencies?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Better module imports in VSCode possible?" (#17035)

Issues.Title: [I18n] New locale codes not supported by angular.json
Issues.Body:
According to [I18n documentation](https://angular.io/guide/i18n#setting-up-the-locale-of-your-app), language code such as `zh-Hant-HK` should be supported. Documentation also points you to the list of all [supported locales](https://github.com/angular/angular/tree/master/packages/common/locales) on the angular repo.

It seems however that those codes are blocked by the regular expression defined in the schema.

https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/c9a5f3ced6689feac9cc0ccbd15b0fed6f454d6e/packages/angular/cli/lib/config/schema.json#L416-L420

![Zrzut ekranu z 2020-02-20 16-27-55](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2285385/74949420-080ba180-53fe-11ea-99b8-6dc5ca9c6984.png)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[I18n] New locale codes not supported by angular.json" (#17032)

Issues.Title: Using URL with protocol as baseHref during build removes one slash while using the --localize option
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [x] build - [ ] serve - [ ] e2e - [ ] test - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? The localize option was not available yet ### Description Adding a full URL (https://path.to.assets.app.com) as baseHref to the build command in combination with the `--localize` removes one slash, resulting the base href in the `index.html` to be: ``` ``` This will fail, because the assets will be loaded from a relative url, with this base href appended to it, which is not very nice ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Create an app with localization configured, and run the build command: ``` ng build --baseHref=https://path.to.assets.app.com --prod --localize ``` ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: ng-add doesn't install the latest version correctly
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [ ] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [x] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] xi18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? Yes. With `@angular/cli@8` doesn't cause that error. ### Description In a project created by `@angular/cli@latest`, `ng add` command seems not working correctly. Executing `ng add @ngrx/store`, it throws an error. ``` $ ng add @ngrx/store Installing packages for tooling via yarn. Installed packages for tooling via yarn. The package that you are trying to add does not support schematics. You can try using a different version of the package or contact the package author to add ng-add support. error Command failed with exit code 1. ``` But adding `@latest` to the `@ngrx/store`, it installs and runs schematics of `@ngrx/store`. ``` ng add @ngrx/store@latest Package has unmet peer dependencies. Adding the package may not succeed. Installing packages for tooling via yarn. Installed packages for tooling via yarn. CREATE src/app/reducers/index.ts (359 bytes) UPDATE src/app/app.module.ts (715 bytes) UPDATE package.json (1349 bytes) ‚úî Packages installed successfully. ‚ú® Done in 6.67s. ``` It seems Angular CLI's bug in `ng add` command. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction 1. Create new project with the latest CLI (`npx @angular/cli@latest new my-app`) 2. Execute `ng add @ngrx/store` in the project. ## üî• Exception or Error 

$ ng add @ngrx/store
Installing packages for tooling via yarn.
Installed packages for tooling via yarn.
The package that you are trying to add does not support schematics. You can try using a different version of the package or contact the package author to add ng-add support.
error Command failed with exit code 1.

Issues.Title: MatBottomSheet adds style to HTML root tag <html>
Issues.Body:
#### Bug, feature request, or proposal:
Mat Bottom Sheet adds a style `top:-${scrolled length of the page} px; ` to the <html></html>

#### What is the expected behavior?
Should no manipulate the root Html tag.

#### What is the current behavior?
changes style values in html root.

#### What is the use-case or motivation for changing an existing behavior?
When opening the bottom sheet the Html gets `-random px` and shifts to top so user sees a blank screen behind the bottom sheet.

#### Which versions of Angular, Material, OS, TypeScript, browsers are affected?

These are my angular dependencies
` "@angular/animations": "^8.0.0",

appears on chrome 80.*
MACOS,Windows,Ubuntu.

Issues.Title: Change Detection runs multiple times with material components
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/fork/components-issue

https://components-issue-is9tqp.stackblitz.io/

Steps to reproduce:
1. Click on native select and view console and you'll notice there is no output of "Checking the view"
2. Click on the material select and view console and you'll notice there are 6 outputs of "Checking the view",
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
I would expect there to be a single change detection if the value changed or when the drop-down closes.  There should not be multiple change detections when you click on the mat-select.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?
Change detection is called 6 times when you click on mat-select without changing the selection.  When you click outside the mat-select, change detection is called 8 times.  

#### Environment

- Angular:  8.2.8
- CDK/Material: 8.2.3
- Browser(s):Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows 10

Issues.Title: refactor(dialog): remove custom injector usage
Issues.Body:
Replaces the usage of our custom `PortalInjector` with Angular's `Injector`. The advantage of using the default one is that the injection logic is consistent with everything else and we don't have to require users to polyfill `WeakMap`.

The idea here is to eventually replace all usages of `PortalInjector` with `Injector` and to deprecate it, but I wanted to try it out against `dialog` since it's probably the most used and well tested of the components that are using the custom injector.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "refactor(dialog): remove custom injector usage" (#18565)

Issues.Title: Possible injector-memoryleak
Issues.Body:
I've encountered a possible memoryleak with `angular/cdk` and `angular/core`. I figured this was the spot to post this issue since it has to do with the `overlay`, `componentportal` and `portalinjector`.

#### Reproduction

https://github.com/kbarendrecht/injector-loop-repro
*I tried stackblitz first, but it seems like it's not possible to use ivy there yet.

### Structure
- `AppComponent` attaches a PanelComponent to a `cdk/overlay` and injects `HelloWorldComponent`.

- `PanelComponent` tries to render `HelloWorldComponent` inside a `ngComponentOutlet`.


### Steps to reproduce:
Step 1: Run `ng serve` and open the browser console

Step 2: Uncomment the `p` tag with `ngModel` binding

Step 3: Observe the `PanelComponent.createInjector()` being triggered continuously
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?

_The component being rendered._


#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?

_The component wasn't rendered._

#### Environment

- Angular:
    "@angular/animations": "~9.0.2",
    "@angular/common": "~9.0.2",
    "@angular/compiler": "~9.0.2",
    "@angular/core": "~9.0.2",
    "@angular/forms": "~9.0.2",
    "@angular/platform-browser": "~9.0.2",
    "@angular/platform-browser-dynamic": "~9.0.2",
    "@angular/router": "~9.0.2",
- CDK/Material:
    "@angular/cdk": "^9.0.1",
- Browser(s):
Brave - Version 1.3.115 Chromium: 80.0.3987.87 (Official Build) (64-bit)
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): 
Windows 10 Pro 1909 - 18363.657
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Possible injector-memoryleak" (#18560)

Issues.Title: Mat-menu not allowing key strokes with menu items from components
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: 
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-7-mat-menu (works)
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-9-mat-menu (broken)

Steps to reproduce:
1.  Set up a button to be used with a mat-menu
2.  In the mat-menu, use 2 buttons as well as use a custom component that has just a button
3.  Using the keyboard, tab to your button and then open it, try to navigate using arrows
4.  Only the 2 buttons explicitly listed in the template will navigate, the button from the component will not allow keyboard navigation.  The manuData is missing for that element.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
This was working before we upgraded to version 9.  I have created 2 stackblitzes with the same example.  @angular 7 works,  @angular 8 and 9 do not. 


#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?
The items that are listed as direct children are properly navigated to using arrow keys.  The ones rendered from custom component are skipped.

- CDK/Material: 8.2.3
